Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Medium: The Ectokernel Approach: A Composition Paradigm for Building Evolvable Safety-critical Systems from Unsafe Components

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to develop a new approach for composition of safety-critical cyber-physical systems from a small code base of verified components and a large code base of unverified commercial off-the-shelf components. The approach is novel in that it does not require generating the entire code base from formal languages, specifications, or models and does not require verification to be applied to all code. Instead, an explicit goal is to accommodate large amounts of legacy code that is typically too complex to verify. The project introduces a set of verified component wrappers around existing unverified code, such that specified global system properties hold.
The intellectual merit of the project lies in its innovative approach for managing component interactions. Unexpected interactions are the primary source of failure in cyber-physical systems. A fundamental conceptual challenge is to understand the different interaction spaces of cyber-physical system components and determine a set of trigger conditions when certain interactions must be restricted to prevent failure. The project develops analysis techniques that help understand the different interaction types and provides component wrappers to restrict them when necessary.
Broader impact lies in significantly reducing the design and composition effort for the next generation of safety-critical embedded systems. A variety of student projects are being offered to undergraduates and graduate students. The researchers especially encourage women and minorities to participate. Outreach activity, such as hosting K-12 students on school field/science days, further strengthen the educational component. Technology transfer to John Deere is expected.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed theory, analysis techniques, and software tools for composition of safety-critical cyber-physical systems from a small code base of verified components and a large code base of unverified commercial off-the-shelf components. Unlike techniques that aim to deliver end-to-end verified component code, starting from formal languages, specifications, or models, an explicit goal of this project has been to accommodate large amounts of legacy code that is typically too complex to verify. Hence, rather than attempting to verify an entire software code-base (or generating it from a formal model), the techniques developed in this project allow designers to generate a small amount of code that complements existing unverified code, such that specified global system properties hold. Properties, such as physical stability, require end-to-end analysis of both the computing system and the physical world. Such analysis techniques have been developed, allowing a system to survive both physical and software failures.

The project enhanced our understanding of the different interaction spaces of cyber-physical system components. We specifically considered three types of interactions; (i) functional, (ii) temporal, and (iii) dynamic. The first two refer to interactions affecting system logic and timing, respectively. The last one refers to interactions that affect stability, in a control-theoretic sense. The project helped understand the different types of interactions between components, and compute their impact on run-time safety, timeliness and performance properties of a system.

The developed theory and analysis tools have the potential to significantly reduce design and composition effort for safety-critical embedded systems such as integrated avionics, automotive systems, medical devices, and shipboard computing systems. The results allow designers to significantly improve system dependability while reducing development cost by virtue of better component composition models and more powerful analysis techniques for properties of component composition.
